header.topics: Clothes, food and cooking, travelling, health and illness, exercise classes
header.activity: Friends preparing and eating dinner while chatting.
header.conv_type: Discussing, explaining, inquiring, anecdote telling, making arrangements

body.u: so how much were your bargain buy shoes?
my bargain buy eh twenty-five eh great British pounds
em I don't know whether they'll be water resistant but you know what it doesn't matter they eh they do the job and they'll they'll be fine for work for as long as they last
they've lovely you look
I went I went to em
very smart in black

I went to these em I went to loads of shops I just cos I'd been at work since like quarter to eight and then em my computer completely and utterly screwed up and eh and I just thought you know what I'm here I can't actually do anything and the team in Birmingham actually are struggling so let me let me go up there and then it started raining and then my shoes actually started falling apart on my feet eh

and then I had a look around I went to the Topshop flagship store and like you know the whole thing about like you know disposable fashion and you know it's really cool and buy it it's in and then you know buy something else doesn't seem to work because actually it's really expensive like the prices are
totally and it's still a bad quality
yeah it's like bad quality and really expensive
mm
I just couldn't understand
go figure

so then I went to like you know cos they have the big department stores isn't there like Debenhams House of Fraser and stuff so I walked through all those and I thought if I can find a really nice solid pair of shoes like the brown ones I'd worn for the you know the ballet pumps that I wear there you know to the point that doesn't really notice my fashion know knows exactly what shoes I'm talking about whenever I mention oh your brown ones? Cos when I got them I wore them I think for a year and a half nonstop
and then I thought if I can find something like that and then I did but they were like a hundred pounds and I thought you know what that's ridiculous
one hundred pounds
for little ballet pumps?
and did they look like they were going to last?

yeah I mean they were all like Bertie Pied de Terre and all of that kind of stuff so they were they're pretty solid but if you wore them you would that's exactly what you would say I wouldn't pay a hundred pounds for those
do you want some soup?
no thank you I think this is gonna be quite a heavy protein carb fulfilment but get a glass and have some wine I'm just gonna go and find the can I go?

I'm just gonna go and find the em the Tupperware thing and bring it down
no probs and were you were you supposed to come back tonight?
yeah em I'm going back again tomorrow actually
so you came you came back from London tonight and you're going to London again tomorrow?

yeah but the em the thing I have to be in is for three hours and that's in the afternoon two till five so I'm just gonna work from Birmingham in the morning and also em the whole meeting on Thursday was unexpected and so I didn't really actually have a change of clothes and you know all of that so so I just I wanted to come home and have a good rest
Good idea
Good idea
alright so what do you think of the top this top I bought it in out Urban Outfitters and it just doesn't
wow that's lovely
it doesn't suit me at all because it suited me when I had a suntan but now I'm really pale
well you might get a suntan in the summer and it has a nice holiday top as well
yeah but I'll never get a suntan as much as I had when it suited me so I was just thinking
but it's also a nice holiday top isn't it? To wear abroad
but
if you did get that colour back
if you
I like it
if you like it if you'd wear it the thing is I tried to wear it for work as well with a black
exactly with a cardigan
cardigan but on me it just looks like it's a pyjama top or something and it's because I
what about with em jeans with like light blue jeans?
yeah it's the problem is the the colouring the colouring isn't it?
the face
the colouring of the face or no but I mean if you'd wear it
I'd can I can I
I'm happy for you to have it
try it on after?
yeah sure
but I think it's lovely
no I want you to try it on while you're washing up
while you're washing up and then while you're eating
come on multitask woman
should we go in the lounge? It will be a bit it might be a bit warmer to eat
yeah wherever you want
I think it might be I was just cleaning this pan out because when the climbing boys come back they might want to use it
bon appétit
abso-blinking-lutely
so what's in this? There is em okay I boiled the water
yeah
then put potatoes carrots parsnips onion sweet potato and something else celery
wow

oh put it put it alright down how about that?
and then blended it all up

and then you added the chickpeas afterwards?
yeah I just put chickpeas in now because I needed some something heavy
yeah em
do you want to try some?
yeah thank you mm
like it?

I guess it's the parsnip and the carrot cos there's nothing
yeah
there's nothing else in it at all
God that is so gorgeous
mm
try a bit of this this is em this is just curried tuna almost
how did you do this?
with a god don't don't humour me
go on tell me
very very basic onion and garlic cumin sautéed this is so pathetic I mean I feel embarrassed to tell you
it's not pathetic
I then everything is whacked in peppers tomatoes em masala salt black pepper eh sweetcorn tuna
mm
mixed and mixed together
no it's really nice it's really flavoursome did you put tomatoes in it?
mm
fresh tomatoes or chopped?
four
mm
yeah I did
is that what keeps it a bit moist?
yeah absolutely but then em I don't wait for it to dry out either so while they're all still a bit runny that's when I add the tuna and then just whack it together
mm hm and is that wholemeal pasta?
mm hm
I don't think I've ever tried wholemeal pasta before it's really nice
when you mix it up it doesn't taste bad at all and once you get used to it you prefer it almost
mm it's more eh more eh more eh I don't know
it's like brown bread white bread isn't it?
I do like brown bread especially with seeds in it like that

Warburton's stuff but sometimes white
mm
bread and loads of butter is the best no but that's it's like wholemeal pasta it's like it's more meaty like it's more
absolutely yeah yeah
I'll have to get me some of that
then again whenever I do pasta it's so unhealthy I'm not thinking
why what do you do?
just because I about every I usually do some kind of tuna pasta
mm
with red pepper onions umm a can of tomatoes a bit of garlic
so al almost identical yeah
yeah just without all the spices and
yeah
without the sweetcorn
this is curried up isn't it?
mm it's gorgeous and mine ends up being more like a bolognaise sauce
mm
but the problem then is that I add so much Parmesan cheese
I think I only eat it
really?
so that I can put cheese on it

I find that if I eat it late and cos like when we have pasta Fezel always wants to put you know grated mozzarella or grated any cheese whatever cheese there is he wants to pop it on the top and I find it makes it quite heavy then
mm
especially late at night I mean Parmesan's fine but you know but like full on grated mozzarella then blanketed over melted
I know my Parmesan is never light there's always at least an inch thick I get those little packets you can get from Sainsbury's and they're already grated
exactly
and just stick it all over and then when it melts and goes all stringy hmm
so what's going on with your work stuff now then? What's cos you took a break didn't you?
I'm waiting to hear for a few job applications and and then I'll take it from there
mm
but
and so everything you will do just until September and then you'll start it again?
N oh the course no if I start the course again I'll start it in January because I've already done September to January
mm
so I don't have to do that bit again I would do
so you got a good big breathing space haven't you?
mm hm definitely
do you think it would be okay to pick up from there then so you can just pick up and then
yeah it will be fine it will be easier to pick up from
yeah
that point
yeah
than it was complete exhaustion I've already done the first five months
mm
yeah and em at least I know how much work will be involved so
mm
I'll be able to try I'll try and do some before I'll do
yeah
I'll try and do a lot of it the academic work before
yeah
January so at least I have the
A bit of a head start
mm we'll see what happens
do you miss Spain or are you getting used to it a bit now?
em I miss s spring time
there's no spring here it's like bloody winter
I know yeah no I don't mind winter because there's winter in Spain too it's just
yeah
my body tells me that now this is the time where you start wearing sandals
relaxing a bit yeah it's slightly long Next week is em British Summer Time
no?
it is next Sunday
yeah but the words British and summer time never go well in a sentence together do they? Have you got any holidays planned?
no nothing at the moment
have you got any holiday time still to take?

yeah I think I've got about five days and I'm gonna try and carry it over cos I've got no reason to take it actually cos I wanted to go to India cos you know my mum is and dad they both work for British Airways
mm no I didn't know that
they do my dad was an engineer and my mum worked for a British Airways catering
mm
and they worked for a lo a long time actually
mm
and em so we always had like up to the age of twenty-four we'd have a really good staff discount
brilliant
and eh I mean the the flip side of it was the fact that you were always on a standby list
mm

but the good side of it was that as the years accrued and experience em pardon me and seniority like you know you get up the list a bit so you know it wasn't I mean I've had some disastrous occasions where like I remember one school summer holiday and me my mum and my brother went to India and we spent two weeks going to Delhi like we were staying in Delhi at my auntie's house spent two weeks going to the airport British Airways flight no it's full that flight no it's full that flight no it's full staying there from like the afternoon to two in the morning
oh no

coming back doing the same thing again doing the same thing again I remember doing the same thing in Toronto for a week I mean the the the Delhi one was the worst my dad had to then fly because obviously with him flying we got a bit more seniority
mm

Cos obviously there's a difference isn't there? And em he then had to fly that weekend because obviously school was starting again there I was think I was going to like my fifth fifth form or something and then he had to fly em and with his weight you know we got at least five hundred and two of us got a seat and the other two don't really matter that much and they just waited another few days and it was just because it was crunch time you know end of school holidays
yeah
em and the same thing happened in Canada I remember and it's so soul destroying going there everyday and then like to run into happy passengers
aw
boarding and you're standing on the side cos you have to go and check in first as well
and you just wanna go home

yeah and then you watch everyone check in at the end of the holiday and then they wait and wait and in Canada they were really bad they would take you right up to the gate and at the gate they would tell you so then you would have to ring someone to come and collect you at midnight and go home
oh no and where were you staying then? Wasn't that a problem with your accommodation?

with em family and friends and whoever anyone it's been so random from like close family to absolute randomness and there was one time actually in Delhi when I I did I did get stuck and and because it was quite a sure safe seat and then what happened was there was fog and you know loads of flights were delayed and whatever what happened in this instance was that I'd come from the Punjab I'd travelled down for five hours and friends not even my family friends of the family these like they had said oh you know they took me out for like nice dinner and they said you know cos it looked it was quite a clear flight and they said oh you know fine bye bye whatever and then dropped me off at the airport and then about an hour later this like horrible mist started developing and then all the flights were grounded they were grounded for five hours and all I could ring was my dad up in the Punjab and let him know what was going on and I kept I didn't I didn't you know really want to ring these people cos it's like you know coming up to midnight and I thought I don't want them to come all the way you know forty minutes in to come and collect me and stuff
yeah yeah

and I didn't know when I'd be sort of flying anyway I was there till like two three in the morning and then like my dad had to like properly coach me and he was like okay so em you know em what you have to do is you have to say you know on p proper BBC voice you have to em you know act really official don't try and be nice be really you know and he was like really coaching me and it absolutely worked cos in the end they were like okay madam you know come and stay you know we've got a hotel for these occasions you know so they put me up and they really took good care all of a sudden
how go on give me an impression of how you did it
so I was just like em hi yes I'm fly eh yes so I'm a BBC journalist and I'm flying back to London you know my flight's been delayed I don't have family nearby em you know can you put me up please
do it
yeah
that happened to me in Sri Lanka once we em we were flying from Trivandrum to Sri Lanka from Sri Lanka to Heathrow
mm
and we were getting on the plane to come back to Heathrow from Sri Lanka
mm
and they were all they were all these loads of or loads of men in orange like Guantanamo overalls crawling all over the plane on on the ou on the exterior of the plane
yeah
and everyone was like that's a bit strange what's going on here?
mm

and then as soon as we had all sat down they were like sorry there's been a delay everybody off and they put us in this tiny waiting room and the men the orange men we could see them they were still crawling all over the plane and this was like mm I'd have to say happening for about five hours and wouldn't let us out or to go to the toilet or to get water or anything and there was nothing in there and so there was this huge mutiny Everyone was like you must let us out we have to go to the toilet you must provide us with water at least and em to be able to go and get some food and they were just weren't giving us any information about how long the delay would be or when they would be able to let us out to go to the toilet and I think in the end they let us out and they gave us some free food but then by then it was like we'd been waiting for twenty hours They cancelled the flight but it was only because we made a a huge stink about it
yeah
but they said okay alright we we'll book a hotel for everybody
yeah
but had we not said anything
they would've they would've have been fine
yeah

Cos that was the other daunting prospect I mean leaving the hotel at sorry leaving the airport cos they said oh come back tomorrow you know just it's not safe to fly now and that was the other thing like leaving where the hell would I go and I wouldn't trust a taxi driver with all my luggage and just me at two in the morning to take me to the right place
definitely
alive
so what was em what were you going to say that you were thinking of going to India but could you fly?
yeah
with these special priced seats then?

yes so basically my mum and dad get like a couple of free tickets a year so like you know because they're both retired and stuff and that's sort of what happens and em and so like my dad can have one fellow passenger and my mum can have one fellow passenger and because you know politically because my sister is married and there's three of them so then my dad picked my brother and then my mum picked me and my mum and dad are going to India so basically I would have flown with them and obviously because of the years of experience that we always get upgraded to at least business class
mm
it's just absolutely great you know flying with flying with them now is not have we got a seat it's are we in club?
it's the it's like you know if you don't get that flight and then the disappointment no we're in world traveller plus aw
mm so can the if if they get free? So if your parents can invite somebody to accompany them? Is that still like a standby seat?

no well actually it's a standby seat but it's so high in the priority it's so so what happens is this is a whole big long thing right so basically like with anything they overbook so they you know seven hundred seats they will book for eight hundred and fifty knowing full well there'll be cancellations people won't get there in time people will lose their passports
mm

all that kind of stuff so there's always seats but as it gets to your em like crunch holiday time so Christmas holidays Easter holidays and stuff sometimes and they're you know it some it used to happen quite a lot in the past but now there's like a big you know mushrooming of budget airlines and stuff there's so many airlines but before when they were the standard carriers what would happen is you know where airlines would make a mistake where there's like an overbooking actually when people are desperate to get back and then they did say and then they get stuck you know in the nineties they started these alliances
mm hm

so you just pass them on so you know British Airways you know pass their passengers over to Qantas and say you know I'm sorry would you mind flying with we'll upgrade you to first class or business class or something and
mm

you know circumvent it that way so there's a little bit of that going on but then normally they em they don't fill the seats so that's when you have you're you can have sometimes like fifty standby passengers actually I mean this was back in the day you know
mm
there were like they were the standard carriers now there's
yeah

you know air travel is cheap and all of that and so the everything's slightly different but most times you could have you know up to fifty passengers so actually then it comes to priority and the more you know the more experienced you are like my dad had like eighteen years of experience at British Airways
mm

so he over the years accrued you know priority and we got pushed up the chain so actually you know retired people almost I think out of due obligation and certainly this was honoured in the past would you know experienced retired people would obviously be the first sort of you know you travel like normal passengers they wouldn't even really need to go into a standby list
no

and that's the same with us really so we now I mean the last time I flew I suppose with them was in two thousand and nine and that was em to Calgary and it was peak time it was peak of the summer holidays and em it was you know in terminal five British Airways we got there and literally what we did we checked in I treated them to Carluccios we have this really great lunch which I'll come back which is funny and then we went back and they said yes and then they gave us four club class seats and we just walked straight through and went to the you know executive lounge chilled out and then went straight through
brilliant I'm surprised they still do free flights nowadays cos British Airways were cutting loads of

well they had a you know the year that my dad was made retired which was two and a half years ago that's when they introduced look either we're going to make further cuts or for three months we want eight hundred staff to work without pay what do you prefer?
what? For three months? It's crazy
I mean this was a a proposal
mm
I think I think it was rejected by the unions
not surprised not surprising

it was almost a case of if you want your job if you want to keep your job you have to work you know for nothing or absolute minimum you know for a little while until we get over this em and I think it was rejected and you know my dad poor thing you know he had a year to go to retiring and you know he was first in the line wasn't he? He took it quite badly cos he actually expected to stay for another year so it was quite hard actually
aw
still getting over it
what so he had to retire a year earlier?
mm
did that affect his pension?
I'm not sure I do I don't know much about his
but eh why did it affect him? Just because he wasn't ready to stop working?
yeah emotionally it affected him completely and utterly because suddenly you know you have to mentally prepare for such a transition in your life
yeah true
and to like have spent your whole life doing something and then all of a sudden told you've got three months it's a bitter pill to swallow
yeah
and then what the hell do you do with the rest of your life you haven't like got yourself geared up for that
mm yeah well we'll probably be em we won't have any memories when we retire we'll be like eighty and shuffling around with walking sticks
we hope
so what happened at Carluccios?

so we sat there on this little table a really small little table me my mum my dad and my brother and then em like there was quite a long table next to us and then there was like this guy looked like a a guru like a priest you know almost like you know if he was bare you know bare chested he would have looked like Gandhi kind of thing you know like really really old and blah blah blah but he was in like mass like negotiations let's say he obviously had his business team all around him they were like oh you know and they were talking like high level marketing and they were talking about like high level economics to the point that I couldn't really understand you know but I knew it was so
were you eavesdropping?
so they were they sat as close as you were I suppose
oh okay

but on a a longer table and but they were like really and he was like especially like you know with his team they were like really hammering something but they they were all sort of leaning forwards they were like blah blah blah strategy structure something something like really going for it and then em and then all of a sudden I so we just carried on we're just like eating eating you know but kept looking over like eating eating and thinking who the hell is this guy he must be someone quite famous right? But none of us recognised him off the telly so we carried on eating and then all of a sudden like this one of his one of his cronies went and brought this little old lady over and so she walked over and then she came up and we just heard her she's like oh guruji I I'm so glad I've met you I've come all this way and I wanted to catch you before you left England and then all of a sudden the whole team were like completely like in this Zen like aura and he was just like oh my god yes thank you I just have a simple glass of milk Like he bloody ate a steak a minute ago
and what?

and he was like and then she was like oh thank you I want to so obviously they're doing that like classes and where like you know this practice and that practice and whatever and he's like and he was like all of sudden he's like you know really really we were like you little phony
what kind of guru was he?
God knows little he was too busy talking about what money he was making rather than what he was bloody preaching
the poor little granny god knows how she got to terminal five
aw
it wouldn't surprise me if he was some kind of yoga guru
Exactly going back to India
the one the Ashtanga one em what's his name? Betabi Joy he's been really slated by a lot of fellow yogis in India for pushing the marketing side and America and
well it is a money
making a profit
you know

it's not something personally I'd aspire to

no
yes making lots of money but
no but that's it isn't it? That's where you know he works with you know Hollywood stars they're all nuts this Madhuri yesterday she's so like a you could tell that she was a bit of a prima donna
oh the famous girl?
yeah
is she art is she an actress?
she she dominated Bollywood in the nineties
oh yeah yeah yeah you said
she was absolutely massive in the nineties she was on that
and now she's reclusive

yeah well not reclusive what she did was she moved out of Bombay and she moved over to America she met a guy a surgeon which her brother had like fixed them up on a blind date and actually he had never even watched any sort of Bollywood film so you know he didn't really play into that sort of hype actually and what was really lovely was then you know what she wanted to do was settle down and have kids and all of that kind of stuff and she did it in Denver with him and it's now that she's looking to make a bit more of a comeback I suppose and so they're now living between you know Denver and Bombay but you could tell you know y like basically in the nineties the whole sort of romantic era all those love stories of Bollywood she was like the main she always had like a bit of Whitney Houston type like innocence sweet
mm
pretty features you know like really good clean wholesome lovely girl
yeah
kind of thing and em
so is she going to make a comeback to films now?

she made it about three years ago and then she denied it was a comeback she just said look I have been in the industry but it was so funny so like this new presenter not new presenter but the presenter hadn't really done this sort of thing before and she had like a little sugar plum fairy more overdressed than the poor little Bollywood actress you know like really went for it and like there was one point when like the produc like my colleague held up a white card to say you know we can't hear something was wrong with the earpiece thing
uh-huh

so they had to take their earpieces out there was interference or something and so she kept holding the card like you know behind the actress to say take you know take you earpiece out something take your earpiece out and em and she and then so but she just kept going
and then in the end Madhuri turned around and she said I think that white piece of paper there's an instruction should we just stop and see what what it's says
oh she hadn't realised it was?

so then the girl ran on the stage and she's said I'm really really sorry can you just take your earpiece out can you just take your earpiece out? darling
darling
can't be done I'm afraid I find it quite funny the way that all the women on TV like on the you know the national lottery shows and the Dancing With the Stars and all that

they're all dressed up beautifully but you can see that they've got this big they look like the hunch back in Notre Dame

because they've got the big
cable
big box underneath their dress

what is it? Is it for the mic? Yeah they've probably got one of those

it's kind of similar like a radio mic so the whole sort of em earpiece thing they've got a little bit in their ear as well but it with their big hear hair it's sort of kinda very discreetly comes over and you can't see it cos their hair is down

so you can't see it
ah I'll have to tell my dad he's to start wearing a hearing aid I'll have to tell him that he should grow out his hair
but you can get really discreet hearing aids that just that don't get over the ear that go right in there right?
yeah yeah he's got quite a discreet one actually he doesn't care at all what
yeah
what he looks like
well I I was going to say I bet he doesn't really mind?
he doesn't he doesn't particularly like wearing it but it's not because it

it doesn't look aesthetic

when he was having em the radiotherapy for the skin cancer on his face the he had to have radiotherapy for like
when was that?
eh last month
you didn't say anything

eh it's all preventative it's not it's nothing it's not it's not treatment for something that's still there cos they cut it out and the radiotherapy was just as a precaution to make sure that they got it all
and zapped it up
yeah
when where was it though?
right here on the cheek bone
okay so away from the eye
yeah just like but right under it but em so they made an incision and snipped out what they could
yeah

what probably more than they thought that they needed to but just as a precaution they wanted to give him some treatments anyway when he was having the treatment he had to have it for consecutive days over a week's period and so the the surgeon drew on with em permanent ink like this big box on his face he was like it's permanent do you mind keeping it on for the seven days so we don't have to keep drawing it every day and dad was like no no problem and my mum was like you will not go out of the house with a big black box drawn on your cheek bone So my dad doesn't care he's like yeah whatever
has it all being cleared up?
em he'll have to wait and see but you know because it was
you didn't mention anything
aw well he was quite chilled about it it's it was a I can't remember what the name is? Basal cell carcinoma which is not at all very aggressive
what does that mean?
it's a very it's one of the least aggressive forms of skin cancer
okay so very benign

yeah yeah so and very treatable that's the thing nowadays cancer obviously it's still got that those feelings of attached to the word cancer hasn't it? But a lot of cancers are treatable nowadays I don't think it needs to be so scary

we'll I've lost em my mum's sister one of my mum's sisters died from cancer the other sister has just gone through a second you know she had cancer fifteen years ago and it's just reoccurred and so actually you know it's been quite traumatic and cos it's spread to she's had a kidney removed and it's been quite she's a single parent it's quite traumatic
oh dear
em and eh my auntie has just em had cancer near her thyroid so you know
Dodgy

and that was a couple of weekends ago so I need to see her next weekend but that's so I don't take it lightly actually and my em family side we were very close to em em you know how it happens you know like my one of my dad's best friends his you know we and his wife my mum and dad were very good friends with them and it just so happened that when we were growing up we'd spend like every sort of Friday night we'd go round for dinner you know the kids would all play board games and stuff like that and and I was very attached to their mum actually I just you know even to the point that when I was little I used to say you know in Punjabi terms if I ever had a you know if I had anyone close to her as my mother-in-law I'd be the happiest person in the world she is like the perfect mum
aw
you know and and she died from cancer and so it came back and em
oh dear
so I sort of you know
how how old was she?
we're both scared of it she was about fifty-six
really?
yeah very young
and what kind of cancer did she have?
breast cancer again
aw poor thing

whereas my auntie who died my mum's sister you know hers like properly spread all over you know and that was that was a really long drawn-out affair because it started I can't remember where it started in kidneys or the stomach or something but it spread to the back and you know every time you checked up on it like every week it would be in a different you know
oh dear
spreading all over and they flew her everywhere I mean they flew her to America to Germany to you know everywhere they had any miniscule hope of you know curing it and it's costly as well
yeah it must have it must have cost a lot of energy concentration health money aw how long did that go on for?
A couple of years cos they thought it had cleared up or at least stabilised and then it kept going
aw

and the kid and the kids wouldn't accept no for an answer in particular her young son he wouldn't give up so it destroyed the whole family because you know they were very very you know they separated they haven't spoken to the eldest son since but the whole family just sort of fell apart
no
